78460.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6h00v","text":"Grow your bacteria to your target OD600 using the same culture conditions that you will use in your experiments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":36,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2lp42","text":"Create a 10-fold dilution series of your bacterial culture. Use glass beads to seed an LB agar plate with 100 µl of the 10-4, 10-5 , 10-6, and 10-7 dilutions of each subculture and incubate overnight. These dilutions typically yield a suitable number of colonies for accurate counting by eye. If they do not, you will need to adjust up or down depending on the exact details of what you are doing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":122,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":128,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":135,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":145,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gqlb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"entl7","text":"Count colonies the next day, and calculate how many colony-forming units (CFUs) are present in 1 mL of culture.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"da1pf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2g7g8","text":"CFU/mL = (# colonies × dilution factor) ÷ 0.1 mL ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ejpda","text":"Infect 150 µL bacterial culture with 10 µL phage, respectively, from 10-fold dilution series of phage stocks. Aim for dilutions that will give you single countable plaques. Mix with with 3 mL of 0.5% (0.5 g/100 mL) agarose dissolved in LB supplemented with 1 mM MgSO4, pour onto LB plates, and incubate at 37 °C overnight.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":23,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":266,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9gta","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4q5ij","text":"Count plaques the next day, and calculate how many plaque-forming units (PFUs) are present in 1 mL of phage stock.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1vb0h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52ech","text":"PFU/mL = (# plaques × dilution factor) ÷ 0.01 mL ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eqk2t","text":"In our experiments, we generally aim for an MOI of ~10 to ensure that the majority of cells are infected with phage. However, you will need to determine the MOI appropriate for your experiments based on the biological phenomena you are studying. We also aim to have the phage volume be \u003c= 10% of the bacterial culture volume. So, we might use 500 µl of bacterial culture and 50 µl of phage stock. Again, you will need to determine which volumes are appropriate for your experiment. Here is how we calculate MOI using PFU/mL and CFU/mL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dh475","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ank03","text":"PFU/mL × phage volume in mL = Total PFU","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6vs22","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7d0lh","text":"CFU/mL × bacterial volume in mL  = Total CFU","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bduq6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94la1","text":"Total PFU ÷ Total CFU = MOI","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"dfo5e","text":"This protocol outlines how to infect E. coli and B. subtilis with phage T4 and SPO1, respectively, and harvest cells at set time points.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":37,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":49,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cq69e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7k28c","text":"Harvesting cells at different timepoints during infection allows you to evaluate when bacteriophage transcripts are most abundant in cells and maximize their enrichment for downstream analyses such as chemical analysis and RNA sequencing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
materials_text: {"blocks":[{"key":"6tlha","text":"50 mL sterile Erlenmeyer flasks ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b9sv","text":"5 mL sterile and capped test tubes ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3afsr","text":"1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ad3c","text":"Bechtop centrifuge capable of cooling","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1i5d1","text":"Shaking incubator ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8uj42","text":"Shaking mixer","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86b3p","text":"Liquid nitrogen and cryogenic container for safe handling ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37d4n","text":"Freezer at –70 °C or above","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"734r2","text":"Prepare 30 mL subcultures of E. coli and B. subtilis at 1:100 dilution (300 µL in 30 mL) and grow to a target OD600 of 0.4 in a shaking incubator (180 rpm). For both E. coli and B. subtilis this is ~2 h at 37 °C. Supplement the subculture media (LB) with 1 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":29,"length":8},{"style":"italic","offset":41,"length":11},{"style":"italic","offset":166,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":178,"length":11},{"style":"sub","offset":112,"length":3},{"style":"sub","offset":264,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":279,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d90g7","text":"Aliquot 500 µL of cell culture into several 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes and inoculate with 50 µL of phage at the correct dilution to reach your target MOI (see our protocol on MOI calculations, linked below).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bksu4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b81k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"protocols","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"id":78460,"title":"Calculating multiplicity of infection (MOI)","title_html":"Calculating multiplicity of infection (MOI)","load_collapsed":true,"uri":"calculating-multiplicity-of-infection-moi-cqu4vwyw","image":{"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/kx99bx3af.jpg","webp_source":null,"placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/kx99bx3af.jpg","webp_placeholder":null},"creator":{"name":"Arcadia Science","affiliation":null,"affiliation_url":null,"username":"arcadia-science","link":"https://www.arcadiascience.com/","image":{"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ksusbx3af.jpg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ksusbx3af.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ksurbx3af.webp"}},"stats":{"number_of_steps":5},"type_id":1,"guid":"A7D31110BFA511EDAC46EB9769C558F0"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dru8q","text":"Pre-cool a bench-top centrifuge to 4 °C and at desired time points, harvest cells by centrifuging at 5000 × g for 3 min. For example, cells can be harvested at 5 min and 15 min in the hope of capturing both earlier and later infection stages. This timing will be highly phage-dependent! ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"69og0","text":"Remove the supernatant from the pellet and immediately flash-freeze the pellets in liquid nitrogen. You must be speedy during this process to effectively halt phage infection. You can store bacterial pellets at –80 °C and use later for downstream applications such as RNA extraction. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5qk74","text":"Plate out phage and bacteria to calculate the actual MOI used in the experiment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86tmf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2us29","text":"Here, we are infecting E. coli with T4 and and B. subtilis with SPO1.  Be sure to simultaneously carry out a control experiment where you mock-infect 500 µL E. coli and B. subtilis cultures with 50 µL sterile SM buffer. Once inoculated, incubate the microcentrifuge tubes at 37 °C on a heated shaker block, shaking at 300 rpm.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":23,"length":8},{"style":"italic","offset":47,"length":11},{"style":"italic","offset":157,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":169,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

title: Phage infection and timed harvest of E. coli and B. subtilis cells
title_html: Phage infection and timed harvest of E. coli and B. subtilis cells
